contentrichtext.text: '''Leonard Nelson''' (July 11, 1882, [[Berlin]] – October 29, 1927, [[Göttingen]]) was a [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]] and [[philosopher]]. He was part of the [[Jakob Friedrich Fries|Neo-Friesian School]] and a friend of the mathematician [[David Hilbert]], and devised the [[Grelling–Nelson paradox]] with [[Kurt Grelling]]. During his doctorate at [[Georg August University of Göttingen]] he was advised by [[Julius Baumann]], and his dissertation was titled ''Jakob Friedrich Fries und seine jüngsten Kritiker''. He was critical of [[Hegel]] in his work, ''Progress and Regress in Philosophy''. He is also known for defending the idea of [[animal rights]] in his work ''System of Ethics''.<ref>Nelson, Leonard, ''System of Ethics'', Yale University Press, New Haven, 1956, p. 142.</ref> Together with [[Minna Specht]] he was the founder of [[Internationaler Sozialistischer Kampfbund]].
